tn.text: Parallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_poetry]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
Possible meanings are 1) David wrote the psalm or 2) the psalm is about David or 3) the psalm is in the style of David's psalms.

The phrase "lift up my life" is a metaphor. Possible meanings are 1) the writer is giving himself to Yahweh, which means he is completely depending on Yahweh. AT: "I give myself to you" (UDB) or 2) he is offering prayer and adoration to Yahweh. AT: "I worship and adore you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: Do not let me be humiliated
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "Do not let my enemies humiliate me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"ashamed"

"rejoice in triumph over me." The phrase "over me" implies that his enemies have defeated him and stand above in victory. AT: "defeat me and rejoice about it" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: May no one who hopes in you be disgraced
tn.text: "Do not let those who hope in you be disgraced." Disgrace could come from being defeated by their enemies. This can be stated in active form. AT: "Do not let enemies defeat those who hope in you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"who trusts you"
"act deceitfully" or "act with trickery"
"without a reason"

tn.ref: Make known to me your ways, Yahweh; teach me your paths
tn.text: Both statements mean the same thing. God teaching a person how they should behave is spoken of as if he were showing a person the correct path on which a person should travel. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"I depend on you" or "I wait patiently for you"

tn.ref: Guide me into your truth and teach me
tn.text: Guide and teach mean the same thing, to give instruction. AT: "Instruct me to conduct my life by obeying your truth" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
The abstract noun "salvation" can be stated as "saves." AT: "the one who saves me" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

This is an idiom. This does not mean God forgot something. The writer is asking God to think about and consider his acts of compassion and faithfulness. AT: "Remember" or "Think about" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: your acts of compassion and of covenant faithfulness
tn.text: The abstract nouns "compassion" and "faithfulness" can be stated as adjectives. AT: "how you have been compassionate and faithful to me because of your covenant" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
Here "they" personifies God's compassion and covenant faithfulness. AT: "for that is how you have always been" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])

tn.ref: Do not think about the sins of my youth
tn.text: The abstract noun "sins" can be stated as "sinned." AT: "Do not think about how I sinned against you when I was young" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
The abstract noun "rebelliousness" can be stated as "rebelled." AT: or about how I have rebelled against you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
This is an idiom. This does not mean God forgot something. The writer is asking God to think about him. AT: "Remember me" or "Think about me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: with covenant faithfulness because of your goodness
tn.text: The abstract nouns "faithfulness" and "goodness" can be stated as adjectives. AT: "and be faithful to me because of your covenant, because you are good" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
How God wants a person to behave is spoken of as if it were a way or path on which a person travels. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
This nominal adjective can be stated as an adjective. AT: "humble people" or "those who are humble" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_nominaladj]])

tn.ref: All the paths of Yahweh are steadfast love and faithfulness
tn.text: The word "paths" is a metaphor for ways. AT: "Yahweh always loves us because of his covenant and he is always trustworthy" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
The phrase "your name" here refers to Yahweh's reputation. AT: "For your reputation" or "So that people will honor you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: pardon my sin, for it is great
tn.text: The abstract noun "sin" can be stated as "sinned." AT: "please forgive me, for I have sinned much" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

tn.ref: Who is the man who fears Yahweh?
tn.text: This question introduces "the man who fears Yahweh" as a new topic. AT: "I will tell you about the man who fears Yahweh." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: is the man who fears ... instruct him ... he should ... His life ... his descendants
tn.text: This does not refer to a specific person. AT: "are those who fear ... instruct them ... they should ... Their lives ... their descendants" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_genericnoun]])

tn.ref: The Lord will instruct him in the way that he should choose
tn.text: Yahweh teaching people how they should behave is spoken of as if Yahweh were teaching the people what way or path they should travel. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: His life will go along in goodness
tn.text: "God will cause him to prosper" or "God will cause them to prosper"

tn.ref: The friendship of Yahweh is for those
tn.text: "Yahweh is a friend to those." Some translate it as "Yahweh confides in those." His confiding in them shows the intimate friendship he has with them.

tn.ref: My eyes are always on Yahweh
tn.text: Here "eyes" represents looking. Looking to Yahweh is a way of saying he is asking Yahweh for help. AT: "I always look to Yahweh" or "I always ask Yahweh to help me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: for he will free my feet from the net
tn.text: A net is a trap. A person who is in danger is spoken of as if their feet are tangled in a net. AT: He will rescue me from danger" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Yahweh paying attention to a person and considering him is spoken of as if Yahweh were physically turning towards the person. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: The troubles of my heart are enlarged
tn.text: Here "heart" represents a person's emotions. AT: "I feel more and more troubled" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: draw me out from my distress
tn.text: "bring me out of my distress." This speaks of distress as if it were a place that a person can be brought out of. AT: "rescue me from my distress" or "relieve me of my distress" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
The word "distress" is an abstract noun. AT: "the things that distress me" or "the things that cause me to be afraid" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
"Notice my affliction"
The abstract noun "affliction" can be stated as a verb. AT: "the things that afflict me" or "how afflicted I am" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
The word "toils" is an abstract noun. AT: "the things that trouble me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

tn.ref: they hate me with cruel hatred
tn.text: "they hate me cruelly" or "they hate me fiercely"

tn.ref: do not let me be humiliated
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "Do not let my enemies humiliate me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Going to Yahweh for protection is spoken of as taking refuge in him. AT: "go to you for protection!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: May integrity and uprightness preserve me
tn.text: This speaks about "integrity" and "uprightness" as if they were persons who could keep another person safe. These abstract nouns can be stated as adjectives. AT: "May being honest and doing what is right preserve me" or "Preserve me, Lord, because I am honest and do what is right" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
"keep me safe"
"Save Israel" or "Redeem Israel"
Here "Israel" represents the people of Israel. AT: "the people of Israel ... our troubles" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
